item.title: [NOT] Welcome to /biz/ - Business & Finance — 1 replies
item.content:encoded:
[NOT] Welcome to /biz/ - Business & Finance

Open thread • Replies: 1

OP

This board is for the discussion of topics related to business, economics, financial markets, securities, currencies (including cryptocurrencies), commodities, etc -- as well as topics relating to starting and running a business.

Discussions of government policy must be strictly limited to economic policies (fiscal and monetary). Discussions of a political nature should be posted on >>>/pol/. Global Rule 3 is also obviously in effect.

Note: /biz/ is NOT a place for ADVERTISING or SOLICITING. Do NOT use it to promote your business, ventures, or anything you may have an interest in. Anything that looks remotely like advertising or soliciting will be removed. Begging/asking (including tipping) for cryptocurrencies or asking for money/capital is also strictly forbidden.

Latest replies

60278993
Check the catalog before posting a new thread!Reply to existing threads about a topic instead of starting a new one. Mods will delete obvious duplicate threads and spam without notice.

>>61856214
Yes — the statement is essentially real, and it comes from an actual European Union initiative, but it’s important to understand it correctly.

Real context:
The European Commission, under the leadership of Ursula von der Leyen, is preparing the Savings and Investments Union (SIU). Its goal is to better connect citizens’ savings with investments within the EU. This is part of a broader effort to strengthen Europe’s capital markets and competitiveness by improving how savings flow into productive investments.

The statement shown in the image (“We’ll turn private savings into much needed investment.”) was posted as a tweet and it does exist. It circulated widely online and sparked public debate.

Important clarification:
This statement does not mean that the EU will seize people’s savings or take money from private bank accounts against their will. The initiative aims to create better conditions and incentives so that citizens who choose to do so can invest their savings more easily through European capital markets. There is no automatic or forced transfer of personal savings.

So, to answer your question:
Yes — the quote is based on a real tweet and a real EU policy initiative. It was not fabricated, but it has often been shared without proper context, which can lead to misleading interpretations.

If you want, I can also explain what the Savings and Investments Union would mean in practice and what concrete measures are being discussed.

item.title: [ETF FANG FNGU HFEA LETF] /LETF/ — 25 replies
item.content:encoded:
[ETF FANG FNGU HFEA LETF] /LETF/

Open thread • Replies: 25

OP

Leveraged ETF General /LETF/

Useful links:
https://www.optimizedportfolio.com/leveraged-etfs/
https://testfol.io
https://www.tradingview.com/

What are LETFs?
ETFs that use derivatives/debt to multiply daily returns of an index (1.25x, 1.5x, 2x, 3x).

Popular tickers
TQQQ (3x QQQ), UPRO (3x SPY), SOXL (3x semis), TMF (3x long bonds), SPXL (3x SPY), SSO (2x SPY), QLD (2x QQQ), FNGU (3x FANG+)


Recommended strategy discussion
HFEA (Hedgefundie's Excellent Adventure) - 55% UPRO / 45% TMF

9 Signal (9Sig)
Quarterly rebalance triggered by 9% growth target. Mechanical, removes emotion entirely.

All Weather Leveraged
Risk parity across economic regimes. Typical: 30% UPRO / 40% TMF / 15% UGL / 15% commodities.

200 SMA Trend Following
Hold TQQQ/UPRO above 200 SMA, rotate to cash or bonds below. Simple, effective, hard to actually follow during crashes.

Buy and Hold
Hold TQQQ or UPRO forever. Historically works over 15+ years but you will see 80%+ drawdowns.

Latest replies

61856685

item.title: [ETH] I think I accidentally built a chain that can’t stall — 12 replies
item.content:encoded:
[ETH] I think I accidentally built a chain that can’t stall

Open thread • Replies: 12

OP

Been working on a blockchain design alone for ~1 year. Not a fork. Not based on ETH or Cosmos. Entirely custom protocol.
noticed something strange while running validator simulations tonight.
Even when all validators go offline, the chain continues producing blocks.
Not fake blocks. Protocol-generated blocks. Deterministic. Verifiable. No consensus break.
This wasn’t originally the goal. It emerged from how ticket burning and slot timing interact.
Current properties:
> 3-second slots
> leader selection via burned tickets (PoAsh)
> protocol generates blocks if leader fails or no tickets eligible
> chain never halts, even under 100% validator failure
> validators can’t stall the chain intentionally or accidentally

Still has bugs (pic related), but if this holds under edge cases, it removes one of the oldest failure modes in blockchain design: liveness collapse.
Still early. Still finding edge cases I didn’t anticipate.

Next test is validator rejoin after extended protocol-only operation.

posting devlogs elsewhere 'cause I kept losing simulation history when threads expire.

devlogs: https://t [dot] me/+2SXaDc7CMYc4MTZh
posting validator logs, failures, and protocol behavior as they happen. easier than losing everything when threads expire.
can answer here too, but threads vanish.

Latest replies

61856681
>>61856673
not really something you can sell. value comes from the network existing and being used, not from owning the design. still focused on getting protocol behavior correct first.

61856673
>>61856571
Probably bullshit, but if it's not just sell the tech and make alot of money

61856669
It added ">17 ' by itdelf. Don't knowwhy. Must have been a glitch. I swear I didn't write it myself.

61856654
>>61856647
>17
no coin yet. still building and testing protocol behavior. economic layer comes after consensus layer is stable.
right now just making sure protocol behaves deterministically under failure conditions.

61856647
>>61856571
Just shill me the coin ranjeesh don't sell me the moon

61856641
youre a fucking nerd

61856633
>>61856613
protocol blocks are deterministic functions of prior chain state and slot number. every node computes the same block independently when no validator proposes one, so no fork emerges.
validators resume normal block production on top of that state when they return. protocol blocks preserve continuity but don’t replace validator economic function.

61856613
>>61856601
How do they sync later? This is going to be running simultaneously on many nodes. If it is so predictable it doesn't require more than one node then I think the advantages of decentralization are lost

61856611
AI sloppa

61856604
>>61856571
>Not X, not Y, but Z.

>It's not X, it's Y

Thanks chatgpt, if I wanted to read ai gen shit, I would just message it myself.

61856601
>>61856588
current simulator shows protocol blocks advancing state root deterministically when no validator is eligible. still testing validator reintegration and fork resistance. bugs in pic related came from vault state transition edge case.

61856588
Well have our boys in the lab run the data and get back to you when we have some results. Son, you might have just saved western civilization.

>This could be done by going with the Judy Shelton idea: gold backed USTs..
That would make it easier to sell more debt, but the problem is, they are at over 100% of their revenue on interest and non-discretionary spending. Ie, more than 100% of their revenue is spent on costs that CANNOT be "trimmed".

Imagine I have no income and live off credit cards, getting new credit cards as I fill up my old ones, and using additional credit cards to pay the minimum payments on all the outstanding maxxed out credit cards.

Now I promise that in 50 years from now I will pay new credit cards I get back in gold.

Do you see the problem? Without reducing the debt by 70%-80% and massively cutting spendng to balance the budget, the very best that would do is add a year or two more rope to get hanged with later.

Republican politicians are so corrupt, they didn't want DOGE to seriously look at all the fraud in the US government, and especially NOT in the military, but EVEN outright scams like NED and USAID are being protected.

At least half of the left in the USA is living on patronage networks funded by US government debt.

I love Judy Shelton and think she's great, but I personally wouldn't trust the US government not to default on my "gold backed" bonds 50 years from now. What are you going to do if the US government pulls another 1971? Bomb them?

The time for threading the needle ended with 9/11 and trillions in regime changes on behalf of Israel, the most expensive parasite in the known universe.

I would be happy if facts can prove me wrong without a collapse. Financial collapse may trigger civil war and/or breakup of the USA.

>>61855985
>That only works if we still have stores of it at Fort Knox and etc
It works (and is necessary) even if the USA has zero gold.

From the POV of revaluing (devaluing) the dollar vs gold, it doesn't matter if the US has 8500 tons or not. Devaluing the dollar is needed to increase American export competiveness. Even if they still had 8500 tons of bars, it would only provide $5 trillion at best, which will soon be merely the annual deficit.

The devaluation of the dollar means the debt gets paid back via much smaller dollars. It is exactly the equivalent of a soft default, paying back 20% of the original value owed.

There is a 100% chance the US dollar will be devalued, the only question is:
-will it be a deliberate, finite, one time big jump
-will it be uncontrolled, ad hoc, chaotic and potentially unlimited

They probably still have a bunch of "coin bars" which are 90% gold that would be re-refined up to .999. This is what the "show off" to visiting politicians who are too stupid to know better.

The only reason why they would still have their coin bars is because if they tried to steal and sell them, any refiner on earth would immediate recognize these came from Fort Knox, so unlike regular fine gold, they couldn't be sold without publicly exposing the theft. The USA has probably been discreetly buying gold ever since they suddenly stopped talking about doing an audit.

As Luke Gromen says:
>All Roads Lead to Gold.
